text: John Updike died on January 27th 2009 he
had been for many years one of America's
most eminent literary men a novelist
short story writer critic poet essayist
playwright and much more besides a
towering figure in our literary
landscape in October mr. Updike came to
The Times building and he and I sat down
for an extended conversation about the
craft of fiction and the art of writing
I don't really think of myself as
writing stylish Lee I think of myself as
trying to write with precision about
what my mind's eye' conjures up so if
out of this the sentences become shapely
and vivid that's great
but I'm really mostly concerned with
trying to deliver to the reader of my
images and my sense of human behavior
and of landscape as to an individual
voice I have written in the first person
in the end it becomes a kind of a trap
the one wouldn't want to call the
masterpieces of first-person fiction
monologues but there is a danger always
of never getting outside of that one
voice and that one hid Philip Roth has
quite a gift which has grown of really
imagining other people other than a
bright Jewish nice boy who doesn't isn't
content with being nice this character
certainly recur as an awful lot to the
point that you begin to feel on the edge
of claustrophobia but he he also has
freed himself up to write about other
people I guess that's my sense of the
writers mission as a member of society
is to try to empathize with other people
get away from yourself insofar as one
can get away from yourself and don't
don't write about writers don't write
indeed about intellectuals but try to
write
ordinary people how is it that you as a
novelist project your characters into
situations you yourself might resist
well maybe I'm secretly drawn to them
having taken flippers advice to live as
a bourgeois of liveth one of the
bourgeoisie I envy the people who are
less bourgeois than and I and you know
we all have anarchic impulses rabbit run
of course it's about the anarchic wish
to kick over everything holding you back
and run he was a runner he had a moment
of grace when he was a star athlete and
and he's trying to recover that so he's
really on a kind of a quest anyway it's
kind of natural I think for a writer to
be try to make the characters think
things and do things that he doesn't
think or do it's exciting that way write
book write about somebody who agrees
with you entirely or even to try to
figure out what you do believe I think
is a kind of a waste of time you review
Toni Morrison's new novel and in the
latest New Yorker a short story not long
ago are you writing another novel now
I'm trying to move one along it's very
sticky and makes me wonder if I agree we
shouldn't hang up my spikes as a
novelist but it involves research and
although I complain about other people's
historical novels I seem to be
attempting one just to see if I could do
it when is it that it's said in the
first century AD oh really and not a
century I know but I'm trying to learn
as I go and I guess it's all educational
maybe I'm too old to be educated
getting to think however yes I'm doing
that and as you say I have kept up
trying to keep my name in the new New
Yorker as a reviewer and after a long
drought as a short story writer I was
happy to have them take two short
stories recently it makes me feel like a
real person somehow to get a short story
into the New Yorker maybe because that's
where I began as a writer as a writer
who could actually make a living so if I
can't write short stories it's a kind of
impotence that I resist having written
so many books over so many years you now
look back and and see periods when you
were writing particularly well do you
feel your powers are not amassed as
thoroughly as as they might have been at
an earlier time I think there comes a
moment when you're still full of
material untouched by you but fresh in
your mind and seeming urgent this is
your life this is what you know emerges
with enough skill to get it down and
that that moment tends to occur in
American writers somewhere in their late
20s or early 30s so we're a nation have
burned out talents and I always thought
I'd resist it I'd be like Henry James
and just right away and use my head and
be patient and productive and emulate
Henry James but it's not so easy there's
a way in which American writer is a sort
of a priest he Hemingway had it those
youthful thing the too youthful novels
plus the short stories are really quite
you know their treasures of our
literature I still try and of course I
have no experience in that I'm aging I'm
also should be I think wise here don't
people get wiser as they age because
they know more what they leave out of
that equation is that you also forget
more I'm not sure it's a net a net gain
but no I I'm not ashamed of my later
work but I do feel
certain energy unforced energy in the
early early stuff and the first rabbit
run is still the novel that people
associate me with even though the latter
to the latter three two of them won
Pulitzer Prizes and we're generally you
know reviewed better but rabbit it's
nice to be as a writer somewhat knowing
but also kind of naive because out of
other than I have day comes the sense of
wonder it's wonderful to be able to
describe this privet hedge in
Pennsylvania and how a guy about the
lady's wife runs his hands across the
privet hedge I mean that's sort of
detail your ability to care about that
kind of detail I think slightly
diminishes I don't think we ever
valorized any life stage beyond youth in
this country so we're all failed youths
that is we were best in life was had
more Savior than we were more glamorous
than oh oh ages ago
we don't believe I think in just very
full of generalizations but we don't
believe in the wisdom of the ages they
don't have a village wise man you know
and especially now that so many people
live forever even less so their park
them in nursing homes and old people's
homes so and you feel that in our great
writers certainly Hemingway and
Fitzgerald you can't say Faulkner but
those two their idea of happiness is to
be young
